header_summary:
Bitcoin developers are exploring advanced privacy measures for transactions, notably through the inception of Octojoin, a mechanism designed to obscure the source of transaction inputs by merging multiple inputs, including those from different users, into a single transaction. This method aims to camouflage these transactions amidst regular bitcoin activities, thereby challenging on-chain analysis and enhancing user privacy. Moreover, Octojoin facilitates swaps and offers a novel avenue for selling statecoins originating from coinjoined UTXOs, with further details and feedback opportunities available on its [official website](https://octojoin.github.io/).

Simultaneously, the blockchain realm has witnessed the introduction of the LS-LSAG scheme, a breakthrough in signature efficiency that shifts from linear to logarithmic in size without compromising security. This innovative scheme, which is compatible with Curve Trees, leverages an inner-product argument to significantly reduce signature sizes while maintaining its linkability and resistance against forgery, predicated on the robustness of hash-to-curve functions. The LS-LSAG's technical specifications and its potential to revolutionize signature schemes in blockchain applications are detailed in a draft for community review at [https://eprint.iacr.org/2024/921](https://eprint.iacr.org/2024/921), marking a pivotal step towards more efficient and secure blockchain technologies.

recent_posts.title: Octojoin: Payjoin with no interaction between sender and recipient
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin developers tackle privacy issues with Payjoin transactions and face challenges.
- Octojoin is proposed, enhancing privacy by mixing multiple inputs to obscure ownership.
- The solution also encourages usage of swaps and statecoin sales, inviting feedback for refinements.

recent_posts.title: A new logarithmic-size signature scheme LS-LSAG
recent_posts.summary:
- Ed Hughes introduced a novel ring signature scheme, LS-LSAG, for blockchain use.
- LS-LSAG offers major size efficiency improvements and full-chain Curve Trees compatibility.
- It ensures unforgeability based on the Discrete Logarithm principle and hash-to-curve collision resistance.

active_posts.title: Proposing a P2QRH BIP towards a quantum resistant soft fork
active_posts.summary:
- The proposal suggests adding quantum resistance to Bitcoin with a new signature algorithm.
- It marks the kick-off for a series of proposals to protect Bitcoin from quantum threats.
- The proposal is open for community feedback to refine and validate the quantum-resistant framework.

active_posts.title: BIP Draft: "ChillDKG: Distributed Key Generation for FROST"
active_posts.summary:
- Tim, Jonas, and Nick are drafting a Bitcoin Improvement Proposal on FROST Threshold Signatures.
- Their draft, including design and a Python reference implementation, seeks community feedback on GitHub.
- Several development areas remain, including finalizing wire format and addressing extension TODOs.

active_posts.title: Bitcoin Core 26.2 released
active_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Core version 26.2 is now available for download with new features and bug fixes.
- Upgrading requires shutting down old software and varies by operating system for installation.
- Significant changes include script handling adjustments and network enhancements.

active_posts.title: Segwit Ephemeral Anchors
active_posts.summary:
- Ephemeral Anchors are introduced to include "dusty" values in key-less output types.
- The approach faces challenges due to vulnerability in transaction ID malleability and integration with protocols.
- An alternative proposes using bip141 with an undefined witness program, adding only 3 bytes.

active_posts.title: Ephemeral Anchors and MEVil
active_posts.summary:
- An anomaly in the "anti-MEVil" mechanism shows when entities increase the ephemeral anchor value.
- A scenario illustrates 'Bob' using 'Alice's funds to conflict with transaction 'TxD'.
- Anti-DoS rules inadvertently motivate inflating ephemeral anchor values, affecting transaction validation.

active_posts.title: Stable Channels - peer-to-peer dollar balances on Lightning
active_posts.summary:
- Stable Channels integrates bitcoin with the Lightning network to enhance stability and investment.
- It minimizes bitcoin's price volatility without needing banks, operating with two user types.
- The project explores trading and risk mitigation, aiming for financial stability on bitcoin rails.

today_in_history_posts.title: BIP 118 and SIGHASH_ANYPREVOUT
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- ZmnSCPxj detailed how a Taproot version of eltoo could utilize a single MuSig key for transactions.
- Update transactions use `SIGHASH_ANYPREVOUTANYSCRIPT` and a monotonically-increasing `nLockTime`.
- Richard Myers queried about the efficiency and possibility of alternative methods in closing channels.

today_in_history_posts.title: Dynamic Commitments: Upgrading Channels Without On-Chain Transactions
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Rusty proposes adding `commit_switch` and `commit_switch_reply` for double-opt-in processes.
- He suggests a linear channel progression and using existing feature bits for upgrades.
- Upgrading to anchor_outputs involves three steps, including a feature bit for upgrades.

today_in_history_posts.title: Deflationary money is a Good Thing
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Investment strategies are divided into passive and active types with specific examples of each.
- The blog discusses issues with passive investment, including asset mismanagement and societal impacts.
- It explores deflationary currencies and proposes central banks back inflationary currencies with them.
